Award.AwardTitle: Regulatory mechanisms controlling photomorphogenesis and resource allocation in cyanobacteria

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Cyanobacteria carry out oxygenic photosynthesis in which the inputs are carbon dioxide and light, and the product is stored energy in the form of sugars, with oxygen being generated as a by-product. This process is very similar to photosynthesis in eukaryotes such as algae and higher plants. As also true of other photosynthetic organisms, cyanobacteria exhibit finely tuned abilities to sense and respond to changes in their ambient environment, including changes in light and nutrient availabilty, by undergoing adaptive processes called photomorphogenesis. The molecular mechanisms for allocating resources to balance the energy demands for photosynthesis (sugar production) with the energy costs of responding to environmental variations (photomorphogenesis) are not well understood, and will be the focus of this investigation.

Broader Impacts: Results from these studies are expected to provide novel insights into the molecular bases of balancing the energy demands of sensing and responding to environmental fluctuations in light and nutrient availability in photosynthetic organisms. In addition to the training of graduate students and postdoctoral scholars and collaborative research and mentoring interactions with students and a faculty member at an Historically Black College and University, broader impacts of the proposed investigations include research and instructional experiences designed to develop the capacity of undergraduate science majors and students from underrepresented groups, including students in the Charles Drew Science Enrichment Program at Michigan State University, to think critically and analytically.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The goals of the project were to assess the molecular mechanisms for allocating resources to balance the energy demands for photosynthesis (sugar production) with the energy costs of responding to environmental variations in cyanobacteria, primarily in response to dynamic light and nutrient cues. During the course of this research, 17 research-based articles (11 experimental articles and 6 reviews) were published detailing the progress of the research. An additional two publications will likely be published after the end of the funding period.

 

Highlights of the progress include the following:

 

Multiple insights emerged related to specific molecular factors involved in cellular acclimation to changing light conditions and nutrient availability. For example, we identified several genes that are critical for mediating potential light-dependent oxidative stress, which are critical for maintaining cellular productivity. We also gained new insights into the mechanisms induced by light to regulate cell shape, which is critical for maximizing cell dimensions and photosynthetic capacity. Additionally, we determined specific factors that coordinate the energy contributions to respond to light availability and nutrient levels, which are critical for minimizing potential cellular damage and maintaining optimal fitness. These advances in our understanding also allowed us to initiate studies to understand how the dynamic regulation by light and nutrients of multiple aspects of cellular responses contributes to organismal fitness and persistence through competition-based assays.

 

This progress has direct implications for use of cyanobacteria in cultivation-based systems for biotechnology applications.

 

Broader Impacts: The funds supported the professional training of 3 postdoctoral researchers, 2 graduate students, 8 undergraduate researchers (academic years and summer undergraduate researchers), and two technical staff. Three of these participants were 3 African-American women. Additionally, funds directly supported the establishment of collaborative research with a faculty member at a Historically Black College and University, which included research and instructional experiences designed to develop the capacity of undergraduate science majors to think critically and analytically. As a part of these efforts, three additional publications related to the broader impacts of effective research mentoring and oversight, including support and culturally competent mentoring of individuals from underrepresented groups in STEM, were published.

 

The research based on increased understanding of the molecular bases of balancing the energy demands of sensing and responding to environmental fluctuations in light and nutrient availability in photosynthetic organisms has broader implications for development of these systems for production of bioproducts from renewable systems.
